Gallery Fun Facts Frequently Asked Questions Links and Contacts Map ListOfGallery Eng //Strings for Links and Contacts Page Links and Contacts General Information Stacy Shane mgrss@appsci.queensu.ca Main Reception reception@appsci.queensu.ca First Year Engineers Aphra Rogers firstyr@appsci.queensu.ca //FAQ Strings Frequently Asked Questions Q) What are all these extra charges I see? LALALALALA //A) University is expensive. However, some of the costs are actually optional. For example, student fees include a health and dental plan, bus passes, and gym membership. If you'd like, you can opt out of those fees. Details here: "http://myams.org/society/about-your-ams/student-activity-fees" hi hi hi hi hi hi hi hi Map EngineeringBuildingsMenu NonEngineeringBuildingsMenu FoodBuildingsMenu HistoricalBuildingsMenu PictureViewCampusMap PictureViewCampusMap2 Dummy Button DUMMY\nCONTENT EllisHallBuilding Location:58 University Avenue Ellis Hall Main Uses Ellis Hall, constructed in 1958, is home to the Department of Civil Engineering, the Queen’s Observatory, the GeoEngineering Centre, and the Groundwater and Flows Research Groups. The observatory houses a 16-inch state-of-the-art telescope used to study astrophysics. Ellis Hall is also home to multiple classrooms and an auditorium, where many first year engineering lectures are held. Interesting Facts Ellis Hall was one of the first engineering buildings at Queen’s University to be built away from the north-east portion of campus. Ellis Hall also houses new and innovative classrooms, with interactive displays and unique seating arrangements, both of which allow for increased group work and participation. These classrooms are used for APSC 100 (Engineering Practice) Module 1, a first year engineering course based on group projects.
